semantic_title: Burns of the Same Anatomic Site - Highest Degree Classification Rule
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > d. Coding of Burns and Corrosions > 2) Burns of the same anatomic site

content.full_text: Classify burns of the same anatomic site and on the same side but of different degrees to the subcategory identifying the highest degree recorded in the diagnosis (e.g., for second and third degree burns of right thigh, assign only code T24.311-). (Evidence: pg no: 81, L79-L80)
content.summary: Rule for coding burns of the same anatomical site with different degrees, requiring assignment of only the highest degree code (Evidence: pg no: 81, L79-L80)
key_concepts: Same anatomic site burn coding (Evidence: pg no: 81, L79-L80)
Highest degree classification priority (Evidence: pg no: 81, L80)
Single code assignment for mixed degree burns (Evidence: pg no: 81, L80)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Classify burns of the same anatomic site and on the same side but of different degrees to the subcategory identifying the highest degree recorded in the diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 81, L79-L80)
detailed_rules.explanation: When multiple degrees of burns affect the same anatomical location, only code the highest degree present (Evidence: pg no: 81, L79-L80)
common_applications: Mixed degree burns on same body part

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify all burns on the same anatomical site
Step 2: Determine degrees of all burns at that site
Step 3: Identify the highest degree present
Step 4: Assign only the code for the highest degree
Step 5: Do not assign additional codes for lower degrees at same site
